To borrow from the language of computers, there are, for the few Westerners living in Baghdad, two basic default settings.
There's lockdown; that's when you choose not to go anywhere because of the risk of being kidnapped, shot or blown up.
And there's fort-hopping.
No one dislikes lockdown more than the Iraqi capital's small corps of foreign correspondents.
These are journalists who live discreetly in the city itself and not in the Green Zone, the giant, tightly sealed citadel in which the US Embassy and the Iraqi transitional government are based.
Lockdown means being confined to lodgings.

To get a picture of the violence that's going on in Baghdad, sometimes within earshot, we rely on mobile telephones and e-mail, on the Arabic-language media and, crucially, on brave Iraqi colleagues who act as our eyes and ears on the streets.
It's frustrating, claustrophobic work of the kind many journalists go overseas to avoid.
As we labor away behind our desks, reluctant prisoners of the conflict, we dream of better days, of fort-hopping days.
In Baghdad, the fabric of some neighborhoods, particularly those housing government officials, wealthy Iraqis or Westerners, has steadily disintegrated over the past two years.

These areas have broken down into clusters of what amount to small, private forts set up by Iraqis who've little or no faith in the transitional government and have decided to take their own measures to try to keep violence away from their front doors.
Baghdad's forts vary in size and type.
Some are just a couple of houses protected by sandbags and palm tree trucks thrown across the road outside.
Others enclose an entire street or three or four blocks.
Many have the sort of defenses that, but for the lack of moats, would have impressed the English in the days of King Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table.
In the residential boulevards of central Baghdad, you see forts wrapped in high concrete barricades and razor wire.
Some are guarded by makeshift watchtowers, manned by squads of privately contracted men with machine guns.
You can spot them even more easily at night.
Baghdad's electricity crisis means much of the city's in total darkness.
But the forts, fearful of suicide bombers, illuminate their entrances with powerful spotlights.
Some Western reporters, a handful, are still courageous enough to work on the streets of Baghdad, though they rarely expose themselves to public view for more than a few minutes.
But over the last two years reporting conditions have grown steadily more difficult.
At the same time, the walls around Baghdad's forts have grown higher and higher.
These days, regrettably, I spend almost no time on the streets.
But I am an enthusiastic fort-hopper.
(Soundbite of humming noise)
When the violence eases off, so does the lockdown.
Then, like mice, we sneak out of our forts and set off across the city to visit someone else's.

Afterwards, perhaps we'll hop on to another, driving nervously through the streets often past an array of armed and sometimes masked groups: the Kurdish peshmerga protecting the presidency; the Iraqi army; the police; the much-feared commandos.
Sometimes during these fort-hopping expeditions, we'll drop in on an Iraqi politician.
Sometimes it'll be an academic or a businessman or a colleague.
Getting into someone else's fort is often the toughest part of the journey.
Sir, they just want to search the vehicle, and then you're allowed to go.
That's fine.
OK.
(Soundbite of door slam)
One fort I've seen was protected by what amounts to a concrete maze, a winding tunnel punctuated by checkpoints.
As you make your way through, the frowns on the faces of the guards grow steadily more skeptical.
It would be imprudent to supply details; suffice to say that if you're entering one of Baghdad's bigger forts, expect to be questioned, frisked, X-rayed and sniffed.
This is, of course, a lot better than lockdown and better still than being blown to smithereens.

Back in April, protests in Sudan ousted President Omar al-Bashir after 30 years in power.
People celebrated in the streets.
One of them was Mohamed Elnaiem, a graduate student in the U.K.
who flew to Sudan to be with his family and advocate for democracy.
He says it was a time of optimism and intense creativity.
People that had been suffocated by 30 years of living under Omar al-Bashir's regime were now communicating with each other and, in open forums, discussing the future.
There was art.
There was poetry.
And there was hope.
Hope that the transitional military council that replaced Bashir would negotiate and give way to civilian rule.
But this past Monday, troops known as Rapid Support Forces - RSF - opened fire on a pro-democracy sit-in in the capital, Khartoum.
Dozens of bodies were pulled out of the Nile.
Earlier today, Elnaiem told me the protestors calling for a civilian government no longer go to the city's main square.
They're demonstrating in neighborhoods.
The idea is basically that they build barricades.

They risk death.
They are scared back into submission.
